Philip Tucker wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
>  
>
>>As well as additive mutations, crossover also results in structure
>>being copied throughout a population and quite possibly faster than
>>deletion mutations can remove them. Also the speciation in standard
>>    
>>
>
>I don't see how crossover can contribute to bloat, though.  A child
>is, structurally, a clone of the dominant parent (i.e., the parent
>with highest fitness).  
>
Ok but consider these points:

1) If you clone a genome and the offspring replaces an existing genome 
that had less structure, then you have increased overall complexity 
within the population.
2) Now if we consider that some additive mutations are neutral then we 
can assume that these will get cloned and propagated through a 
population over time.
3) Overall, mutation is more likely to find neutral additions than 
neutral deletions - assuming equal amount of both types.

Put the three together and hopefully you can see that any reproduction 
mechanism that copies structure will (or can) assist bloat - so long as 
there is some other mechanism adding new structure somewhere. How strong 
this effect is will vary, but any effect at all will snowball in time. 
So if your asexual repro / mutation routine does 50/50 adds/deletes then 
you might expect complexity to remain constant, but throw in the 
additional cloning reproduction mechanism and it may just be enough to 
tip the system into bloat.

I think that makes sense anyway. This also highlights two different 
kinds of bloat:

i) The adding in of new structrure that never existed before (has a new 
innovation ID within the population).
ii) The propogation of existing structure through a popualtion.

Colin.
